newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: FORECAST-S.Africa 97 growth down to 2.5 pct - Sanlam.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-S.Africa 97 growth down to 2.5 pct - Sanlam.

text.p: Sanlam investment company sees South Africa's economic growth slowing to 2.5 percent next year in what chief economist Johan Louw termed a moderate growth recession.
"The South African economy is showing signs of decelerating," Louw said in his October economic survey.

He cited as contributing factors sustained high interest rates, weakening business confidence, a marked decrease in the inflow of foreign capital and expectations of a significant tightening of fiscal discipline in next year's March budget.
"All in all, we estimate that the real economic growth rate will be of the order of 2.5 percent in 1997 in comparison to an estimated 2.9 percent in 1996," he said.
Louw said he did not expect a reduction in the bank rate before the first quarter of next year.

He said an improvement in the current account of the balance of payments and a slowing demand for credit should lead to easier money market conditions, but low foreign reserves would prevent an early relaxation of fiscal policy.
Louw said inflation was likely to rise, but not to double digit levels.
"The prices of consumer services will continue to exert upward pressure on the overall consumer price index," he said.

The depreciation of the rand against foreign currencies, wage increases significantly higher than inflation, a new wave of food price hikes and fuel price increases would keep pressure on the inflation rate.
"We now expect an average inflation rate of 7.2 percent for 1996 and one of between 8.5 percent and nine percent in 1997."
Louw said sentiment towards the rand appeared to be improving and he predicted a stabilisation and possible firming against foreign currencies.

"We believe the rand is currently undervalued and that the prospects for an improvement on the current account of the balance of payments will contribute to a more stable and possibly firmer rand during the rest of this year.
"We foresee that the rand/dollar exchange rate will fluctuate between 4.45 and 4.55 in the next few months," he said.
